info.name: NSO Sample API Requests
info.description:
This only covers a sub-set of the RESTCONF Northbound API, since auto-generated swagger from the application is 200,000 lines of documentation.

Created using https://github.com/NSO-developer/nso-vagrant as a localhost NSO testing environment.

item.name: NSO Root of the App Hierarchy Level Queries Copy
item.description: Note: Root level queries have different headers than other queries. Return All Application and Device Config.

item.name: View Device Config
All Devices in Device List: Show Running-config Devices Device

request.description: Note: This can be a very large payload, since it is sending the parsed running config of every single device in the device list, and the NSO application configuration.

item.name: Single Device Config - Show devices device DEVICENAME
Single Device HW / SW Platform Info

item.description: If device config is very nested, you can use the depth=X parameter to see additional hidden layers of nesting.

item.name: View Existing NSO Service Instances
Get List of Service Instances for a Service

header.warning: This is a duplicate header and will be overridden by the Authorization header generated by Postman.

request.description:
Note: this will only have data if service instances already exist.
Shows all service instances. In this case we have just one. 
CLI version:
admin@ncs# show running-config simple-sample-snmp-server-service
simple-sample-snmp-server-service first_service_instance
 device [ ios0 ]
 dummy  10.0.0.0

CLI version to do the same:

item.description:
NSO allows you to create any service, with any inputs, to enforce any config, for any devices. 

The details for the service can be seen on GitHub.

Code for your reference on GitHub:
https://github.com/jabelk/svi_verify_example

item.name: Commit Dry-Run and Rollbacks

request.description: This is using an example for an IOS interface, with the configuration in the payload, but could be any config. The key thing is having the query params ?dry-run=native so NSO knows to not commit it and to respond back with the dry-run data in CLI format. Postman has the query param in the headers tab.

This is using an example for an IOS interface, with the configuration in the payload, but could be any config. The key thing is having the query params ?dry-run=native so NSO knows to not commit it and to respond back with the dry-run data in CLI format. Postman has the query param in the headers tab.

item.name: Commit-Dry Run Remove IP address from interface

item.description: Commit dry-run is NSO not making any change to the device, but telling you what the proposed change will be based on what is already existing on the device, calculating the difference. Rollbacks are when NSO calculates the minimum number of commands to return it to the previous state of configuration before the NSO commit transaction.

item.name: 1. Create a DNS Server Configuration Template

header.warning: This is a duplicate header and will be overridden by the Authorization header generated by Postman.

request.description:
sample CLI to do the same:
devices template Standard_DNS_Servers
ned-id cisco-ios-cli-6.42
confi
ip name-server name-server-list 8.8.8.8
exit
exit
exit
ned-id cisco-nx-cli-5.13 config
ip name-server servers 8.8.8.8

header.warning: This is a duplicate header and will be overridden by the Authorization header generated by Postman.

body.raw:
<!--
cli for same config
conf
devices device dist-rtr01 apply-template template-name SET-DNS-SERVER
-->

<input>
	<template-name>SET-DNS-SERVER</template-name>
</input>

header.warning: This is a duplicate header and will be overridden by the Authorization header generated by Postman.

request.description:
Groups are useful for organizing your devices in a way
that makes sense to you.

Devices can be a member of more than one group,
and device groups can be nested.

CLI Equivalent

devices device-group campus-devices device-name [ ios0 nx0 ]
top
devices device-group backbone-devices device-name [ iosxr0 asa0 ]
top
devices device-group parent-group-all-devices device-group [ campus-devices backbone-devices ]
commit dry-run
commit dry-run outformat xml
top

header.warning: This is a duplicate header and will be overridden by the Authorization header generated by Postman.

request.description:
This compliance report uses the device config template SET-DNS-SERVER to see if the device has a DNS server per OS type. 
It assumes you have the template in the CDB and have device groups set. The prod instance does not have these set by default.

header.warning: This is a duplicate header and will be overridden by the Authorization header generated by Postman.

request.description:
for a system install the report will be created here:
/var/opt/ncs/state/compliance-reports

item.name: Create Service Instance for Single Device

request.description:
Creates a service and applies the corresponding template. 

to add a package on the sandbox system install do the following:

cd /var/opt/ncs/packages
ncs-make-package --service-skeleton template snmp-servers
vi snmp-servers/src/yang/snmp-servers.yang

** add type string / remove type ip address **
https://github.com/jabelk/snmp-servers/blob/main/src/yang/snmp-servers.yang#L31

cd snmp-servers/src/
make
cd ..
cd templates/
vi snmp-servers-template.xml

** add in the templates **

https://github.com/jabelk/snmp-servers/blob/main/templates/snmp-servers-template.xml#L19

log into NSO
ncs_cli -C
packages reload

item.name: 6. Remove SNMP Community String from Device

item.description: Any element of device configuration modeled in NSO can be configured over the API. The ones given here are just samples. NSO will translate it to the correct commands and can rollback if needed.

item.name: Adding / Removing a Device
Step 0. Create a Device in the CDB

body.raw:
<!--
Sample CLI to do the same thing
devices device dist-rtr01
address   10.10.20.175
authgroup labadmin
device-type cli ned-id cisco-ios-cli-6.44
device-type cli protocol telnet
state admin-state unlocked
-->


<device>
 <name>dist-rtr01</name>
 <address>10.10.20.175</address>
 <authgroup>labadmin</authgroup>
 <device-type>
   <cli>
     <ned-id xmlns:cisco-ios-cli-6.44="http://tail-f.com/ns/ned-id/cisco-ios-cli-6.44">cisco-ios-cli-6.44:cisco-ios-cli-6.44</ned-id>
     <protocol>telnet</protocol>
   </cli>
 </device-type>
 <state>
   <admin-state>unlocked</admin-state>
 </state>
</device>

request.description: Update the Payload with correct info. Sample XML can be used from Get on existing device or using commit dry run on CLI. Device names, NED-ID, Address and Ports will likely be different depending on your environment.

item.name: (not needed on sandbox telent) Step 1. SSH Fetch-Host-Keys Device

request.description:
Since the sandbox is using telnet, we won't need to fetch SSH host keys, but this call is how you would do it if you were using SSH

developer@ncs(config-device-dist-rtr01)# ssh fetch-host-keys
result not-available
info Not available for telnet
is the error given

item.name: Delete a device from CDB Device List

item.description: The production NSO already has all devices added, but you can delete one and re-add it.
